Globally the ACE index (accumulated cyclone energy) per hurricane 1980-2024 shows no increasing trend. Global Hurricane Landfalls 1970-2021 (updated from Weinkle et al, 2012) shows no trend. Satellite data since 1980 shows a slight downward global trend for total hurricaine numbers with 2021 being a record low year. From the NOAA GFDL website 'Global Warming and Hurricanes, An Overview of Current Research' (dated Feb. 9, 2023). And I quote "We conclude that the historical Atlantic hurricane data at this stage do not provide compelling evidence for a substantial greenhouse warming-induced century-scale increase in:  frequency of tropical storms, hurricanes, or major hurricanes, or in the proportion of hurricanes that become major hurricanes." And in November2024 "it is premature to conclude with high confidence that human-caused increases in greenhouse gases have caused a change in past Atlantic basin hurricane activity that is outside the range of natural variability". Multidecadal variability in Atlantic hurricaines is most probably related to the AMO (Vecchi et al, 2021). NOAA data 1851-2021 shows no trend in number of hurricaine landfalls with the record high being 1886. There is also no trend in the frequency of major hurricanes (Cat 3 +) for the same period, although the trend for the last 20 years is downwards. It makes no difference if you look at the Pacific. The average number of typhoons formed for January to September 1951-2022 has declined from 19 to 18 (data source JMA). The busiest season was way back in 1967 with 31. Nothing has even close for over 30 years. We can see typhoon activity trending downwards for over 7 decades.

ðŸ“° Typhoon Ragasa, one of the strongest in years, whipped waves taller than lampposts onto Hong Kong promenades and turned seas rough on the southern Chinese coast on Wednesday after leaving deadly destruction in Taiwan and the Philippines.

In Taiwan, 17 people died after floods submerged roads and carried away vehicles in one county, and 10 deaths were reported in the northern Philippines.

Nearly 1.9 million people were relocated across Guangdong province, the southern Chinese economic powerhouse. A weather station in Chuandao town recorded maximum gusts of 241 kph (about 150 mph) at noon, a high in Jiangmen city since record-keeping began. Black solar panels are the biggest cause of this once-in-a-century weather phenomenon. Solar power generation began as a way to utilize solar energy in an environmentally friendly way, but ironically, no oneâ€”not even scholars, governments, or the United Nationsâ€”realizes that it is the primary cause of our current abnormal weather. This is obvious, however, with a little calculation. Sunlight is low-density, but over a large area it produces enormous amounts of energy. As I've said many times, 1 square meter produces roughly 1 kW. Therefore, 1 square kilometer produces 1 million kW. This is roughly the equivalent of a nuclear power plant. Covering forests and grasslands with black solar panels might produce 20% of the electricity, but the rest will become heat. Plants transpire, and through photosynthesis, they capture sunlight as chemical energy rather than heat. Even in the desert, the reflectivity is higher than that of black panels, and they return light back into space. The meteorological community needs to realize this sooner rather than later. China has installed 5,000 square kilometers of panels. This is where today's major disasters are coming from. If the current climate change were caused by carbon dioxide, the Southern Hemisphere would reach the same concentration within a few months, so it's reasonable for abnormal weather to occur. However, we haven't heard many reports of major disasters from Australia, southern Africa, or South America. This is likely due to the lack of mega-solar power plants. Japan, a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, has remained relatively safe despite its large number of mega-solar power plants. Typhoons and other storms are only partially prevented by China's gigantic mega-solar power plants. However, linear rain bands and sudden heavy rainfall are likely caused by solar power generation.

While it's almost certain that the cause of the devastating disasters is the black solar panels, the worst offenders are the mega-solar power plants built in forests and grasslands. These generate excess heat of the order of 1 million kW in hundreds or thousands of locations. It's inconceivable that climate change won't occur. Meanwhile, those installed on roofs originally made of black tiles are completely unaffected. However, if we want to avoid scorching urban areas, we should increase the number of colored or white roofs. Japan is a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, so we've been somewhat spared so far, but linear rain bands and localized disasters will inevitably increase. We should build white areas near the mega-solar power plants we've already built to return light to space and maintain heat balance. We could also lay white sheets on the undergrowth in forests, which seems effective in winter, but it's unclear how it would work in summer.

The reason for this severe disaster is the fact that mega-solar power plants using black solar power generation are the most important. The worst of these are those built in forests or grasslands. At noon on a sunny day, one square kilometer generates about 60% of the excess heat of a 1,000,000-kilometre nuclear power plant. Japan has 500 square kilometers of mega-solar power plants. Those installed on roofs with black tiles are barely affected. If possible, we should move away from jet-black tiles and use light-coloured or whitish tiles, especially in urban areas. In Japan, ocean current power generation is an immediately feasible alternative to solar power. This method has already been proposed, but even this would change the ocean currents if done on too large a scale. Existing mega solar plants should have white areas around them to return any excess heat generated back into space.

We asked an AI about the impact of the total solar panels in Japan and China. Here's the answer:

A 5,000 kmÂ² area of â€‹â€‹panels receives an average of about 1 TW of solar radiation, of which about 200 GW is electricity and about 800 GW is ultimately released into the surrounding area as heat.

Covering high-albedo areas such as deserts with black panels is estimated to result in an additional absorption (excess heat) of about 250 GW (on average).

While these figures are large enough to alter local weather, their relationship to the global greenhouse effect (COâ‚‚, etc.) requires separate quantitative comparison and verification using atmospheric circulation models (climate models).

To summarize:
The statement that "Even the butterfly effect has an impact, so it's not surprising that such a large energy change would cause abnormal weather" is intuitively and physically reasonable. However, the "magnitude of the contribution" has yet to be quantified academically.

We also asked another AI. See below.
Summary (Conclusion)

Based on assumptions (peak 1,000 W/mÂ², 20% efficiency, 5,000 kmÂ², 5 peak sunshine hours), this would result in an average continuous release of approximately 833 GW of excess heat (equivalent to approximately 833 1-GW nuclear reactors), equivalent to approximately 7,300 TWh of excess energy per year.

The figure is "very large"â€”the local heating potential is not negligible. However, whether this immediately represents the "largest cause of global extreme weather" requires additional climate modeling that thoroughly evaluates local effects, atmospheric circulation, ocean absorption, etc.

People are quitting the evil Party: Too many people are left home to die because they can't afford medical care.

While the CCP is meticulously harvesting people's organs to prolong the lives of its leaders and the powerful, countless Chinese citizens are unable to afford medical care due to their meager incomes. According to the National Bureau of Statistics of China, based on 2019 data, 40% of households, representing 610 million people, fall into the "low-income group" and "lower-middle-income group." Their average annual income is 11,485 RMB, and their average monthly income is "nearly 1,000 RMB" (actually 957 RMB).

Liu Ziyi and Zhao Wei, born in a small mountain village in northeastern China in the early 1980s, wrote in their statement withdrawing from the Young Pioneers and the Communist Youth League: "For as long as I can remember, I've known my mother would often curse Chairman Mao and the Communist Party in our home. From the first day of school, we learned 'History has chosen the Chinese Communist Party, the people have chosen the Communist Party, without the Communist Party there would be no New China.' This conflicted me, but I grew up singing songs like 'Without the Communist Party there would be no New China, Socialism is Good, The East is Red.'"

The memories are still vivid. They say: "The only Communist Party member in the village was also the village chief, and he served as village chief throughout my childhood. But his family became wealthy, while we remained poor. I was admitted to university, but the exorbitant annual tuition of over 10,000 yuan wiped out all our family savings. There were also many other students who took the same exam as me. I went to college, but couldn't afford tuition, so I'm still very lucky."

After graduating, they discovered: "The knowledge I learned in school was completely useless in society. It was incredibly hard to find a job, and making ends meet became a problem. I couldn't spend any of the money I earned, fearing I or my family would get sick, as so many people were left to die without medical care. My house was relocated, and the relocation compensation and my savings weren't enough to buy another one. I didn't fight it much, because I knew so many people had died unjustly due to fighting the government over insufficient relocation compensation, so there was no need to make unnecessary sacrifices."

Discovering how unfair society truly was, unlike the harmonious society they'd learned in school, Liu Ziyi asked his mother, puzzled, why she cursed Chairman Mao and the Communist Party. After a moment's hesitation, his mother recounted a story from her childhood.

"My grandparents lived a simple life, saving enough to buy a few acres of land. Early in the CCP's reign, when my mother was about five or six, our family was labeled landlords because they owned a few acres of land. One night, my mother and her family were arrested and locked up in a small house. A few days later, they were released. Much of the land they had saved up to buy was confiscated, all their property was looted, and the house was divided. Later, even the last bit of land was nationalized. My grandfather was even labeled a "high hat" for this."

It was only after they stumbled upon the Nine Commentaries that they suddenly realized: "China's problems lie at the root. The superstructure, our rulers, the Communist Party, was founded by deceiving and robbing others, and it remains so today..."

They emphasized: "The only way to change this is to break away from its rule and, more importantly, to destroy it (the CCP). If more people understand the true nature of the Communist Party and break away from it, the Party will lose its foundation and will naturally be eliminated. Water can carry a boat, but it can also capsize it. A better life will come to us, so let's make it a reality sooner rather than later!"

Black solar panels are the biggest cause of this once-in-a-century weather phenomenon. Solar power generation began as a way to utilize solar energy in an environmentally friendly way, but ironically, no oneâ€”not even scholars, governments, or the United Nationsâ€”realizes that it is the primary cause of our current abnormal weather. This is obvious, however, with a little calculation. Sunlight is low-density, but over a large area it produces enormous amounts of energy. As I've said many times, 1 square meter produces roughly 1 kW. Therefore, 1 square kilometer produces 1 million kW. This is roughly the equivalent of a nuclear power plant. Covering forests and grasslands with black solar panels might produce 20% of the electricity, but the rest will become heat. Plants transpire, and through photosynthesis, they capture sunlight as chemical energy rather than heat. Even in the desert, the reflectivity is higher than that of black panels, and they return light back into space. The meteorological community needs to realize this sooner rather than later. China has installed 5,000 square kilometers of panels. This is where today's major disasters are coming from. If the current climate change were caused by carbon dioxide, the Southern Hemisphere would reach the same concentration within a few months, so it's reasonable for abnormal weather to occur. However, we haven't heard many reports of major disasters from Australia, southern Africa, or South America. This is likely due to the lack of mega-solar power plants. Japan, a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, has remained relatively safe despite its large number of mega-solar power plants. Typhoons and other storms are only partially prevented by China's gigantic mega-solar power plants. However, linear rain bands and sudden heavy rainfall are likely caused by solar power generation.

While it's almost certain that the cause of the devastating disasters is the black solar panels, the worst offenders are the mega-solar power plants built in forests and grasslands. These generate excess heat of the order of 1 million kW in hundreds or thousands of locations. It's inconceivable that climate change won't occur. Meanwhile, those installed on roofs originally made of black tiles are completely unaffected. However, if we want to avoid scorching urban areas, we should increase the number of colored or white roofs. Japan is a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, so we've been somewhat spared so far, but linear rain bands and localized disasters will inevitably increase. We should build white areas near the mega-solar power plants we've already built to return light to space and maintain heat balance. We could also lay white sheets on the undergrowth in forests, which seems effective in winter, but it's unclear how it would work in summer.

The reason for this severe disaster is the fact that mega-solar power plants using black solar power generation are the most important. The worst of these are those built in forests or grasslands. At noon on a sunny day, one square kilometer generates about 60% of the excess heat of a 1,000,000-kilometre nuclear power plant. Japan has 500 square kilometers of mega-solar power plants. Those installed on roofs with black tiles are barely affected. If possible, we should move away from jet-black tiles and use light-coloured or whitish tiles, especially in urban areas. In Japan, ocean current power generation is an immediately feasible alternative to solar power. This method has already been proposed, but even this would change the ocean currents if done on too large a scale. Existing mega solar plants should have white areas around them to return any excess heat generated back into space.

We asked an AI about the impact of the total solar panels in Japan and China. Here's the answer:

A 5,000 kmÂ² area of â€‹â€‹panels receives an average of about 1 TW of solar radiation, of which about 200 GW is electricity and about 800 GW is ultimately released into the surrounding area as heat.

Covering high-albedo areas such as deserts with black panels is estimated to result in an additional absorption (excess heat) of about 250 GW (on average).

While these figures are large enough to alter local weather, their relationship to the global greenhouse effect (COâ‚‚, etc.) requires separate quantitative comparison and verification using atmospheric circulation models (climate models).

To summarize:
The statement that "Even the butterfly effect has an impact, so it's not surprising that such a large energy change would cause abnormal weather" is intuitively and physically reasonable. However, the "magnitude of the contribution" has yet to be quantified academically.

We also asked another AI. See below.
Summary (Conclusion)

Based on assumptions (peak 1,000 W/mÂ², 20% efficiency, 5,000 kmÂ², 5 peak sunshine hours), this would result in an average continuous release of approximately 833 GW of excess heat (equivalent to approximately 833 1-GW nuclear reactors), equivalent to approximately 7,300 TWh of excess energy per year.

The figure is "very large"â€”the local heating potential is not negligible. However, whether this immediately represents the "largest cause of global extreme weather" requires additional climate modeling that thoroughly evaluates local effects, atmospheric circulation, ocean absorption, etc.

In case anyone is wondering, no that isn't 100 mph winds but it's being reported correctly. Anytime you see wind speeds in an article or news piece, it's almost always the storm's peak at sea. It's the weather agency's estimate at sea, not a land station. Unless it specifically names a location or says onshore or landfall, it's measuring the storm intensity estimate at sea.

Fun fact: Ragasaâ€‹ was actually a replacement name after Typhoon Hagibis was retired in 2019 and what's interesting about it is that the name "Hagibis" means speed in Filipino and also because it's a name givin by the Philippines and oh boy that storm did lives up to it's name where Hagibis unofficially explode in intensity where it's wind increased 130mph in 24H according to meteorology experts and likely peak as a powerful 200mph storm. And of course after Hagibis was retired and replace by Ragasa also a Filipino name, the name is also related to speed and of course this storm also did just that by unofficially peaking at 175-180mph north of the Philippines making it the strongest storm world wide this year after rivaling Cyclone Errol earlier this year on April, which Cyclone Errol unofficially peaked at 180mph, but Ragasa was also the first sub 900mb storm (storm with a pressure lower than 900 milibars, mb for short), so that makes Ragasa both officially and unofficially the strongest storm of 2025.

Think that time, 3 were killed in HK in the New Territories/ out-lying islands, but 20 construction workers were killed across the border in Shenzhen, when their trailer dormitories were torn apart by the wind/ collapsed.

Black solar panels are the biggest cause of this once-in-a-century weather phenomenon. Solar power generation began as a way to utilize solar energy in an environmentally friendly way, but ironically, no oneâ€”not even scholars, governments, or the United Nationsâ€”realizes that it is the primary cause of our current abnormal weather. This is obvious, however, with a little calculation. Sunlight is low-density, but over a large area it produces enormous amounts of energy. As I've said many times, 1 square meter produces roughly 1 kW. Therefore, 1 square kilometer produces 1 million kW. This is roughly the equivalent of a nuclear power plant. Covering forests and grasslands with black solar panels might produce 20% of the electricity, but the rest will become heat. Plants transpire, and through photosynthesis, they capture sunlight as chemical energy rather than heat. Even in the desert, the reflectivity is higher than that of black panels, and they return light back into space. The meteorological community needs to realize this sooner rather than later. China has installed 5,000 square kilometers of panels. This is where today's major disasters are coming from. If the current climate change were caused by carbon dioxide, the Southern Hemisphere would reach the same concentration within a few months, so it's reasonable for abnormal weather to occur. However, we haven't heard many reports of major disasters from Australia, southern Africa, or South America. This is likely due to the lack of mega-solar power plants. Japan, a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, has remained relatively safe despite its large number of mega-solar power plants. Typhoons and other storms are only partially prevented by China's gigantic mega-solar power plants. However, linear rain bands and sudden heavy rainfall are likely caused by solar power generation.

While it's almost certain that the cause of the devastating disasters is the black solar panels, the worst offenders are the mega-solar power plants built in forests and grasslands. These generate excess heat of the order of 1 million kW in hundreds or thousands of locations. It's inconceivable that climate change won't occur. Meanwhile, those installed on roofs originally made of black tiles are completely unaffected. However, if we want to avoid scorching urban areas, we should increase the number of colored or white roofs. Japan is a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, so we've been somewhat spared so far, but linear rain bands and localized disasters will inevitably increase. We should build white areas near the mega-solar power plants we've already built to return light to space and maintain heat balance. We could also lay white sheets on the undergrowth in forests, which seems effective in winter, but it's unclear how it would work in summer.

The reason for this severe disaster is the fact that mega-solar power plants using black solar power generation are the most important. The worst of these are those built in forests or grasslands. At noon on a sunny day, one square kilometer generates about 60% of the excess heat of a 1,000,000-kilometre nuclear power plant. Japan has 500 square kilometers of mega-solar power plants. Those installed on roofs with black tiles are barely affected. If possible, we should move away from jet-black tiles and use light-coloured or whitish tiles, especially in urban areas. In Japan, ocean current power generation is an immediately feasible alternative to solar power. This method has already been proposed, but even this would change the ocean currents if done on too large a scale. Existing mega solar plants should have white areas around them to return any excess heat generated back into space.

We asked an AI about the total impact of solar panels in Japan and China. Here's the answer:

A 5,000 kmÂ² panel area receives an average of about 1 TW of solar radiation, of which about 200 GW is electricity and about 800 GW is ultimately released into the surrounding area as heat.

Covering high-albedo areas such as deserts with black panels is estimated to result in an additional absorption (excess heat) of about 250 GW (on average).

While these effects are large enough to alter local weather, their relationship to the global greenhouse effect (COâ‚‚, etc.) requires separate quantitative comparison and verification using atmospheric circulation models (climate models).

In summary:
The statement that "Even the butterfly effect has an impact, so it's not surprising that such a large energy change would cause abnormal weather" is intuitively and physically reasonable. However, the "magnitude of the contribution" has yet to be quantified academically.

Is it not extraordinary, that in a time when it is thought that most people could care less about the suffering of another, yet here are people, one after another, writing about how profoundly moved they are by the obvious and painful plight of one human being.  It bares out a truism that, though we cannot feel for the masses each of us can respond to the suffering of one individual person.  I am reminded of the idea, often expressed, that to save one person is to save the world.  Thank you for taking this photograph. You have proven, in so doing, that there is yet hope for humanity.

Black solar panels are the biggest cause of this once-in-a-century weather phenomenon. Solar power generation began as a way to utilize solar energy in an environmentally friendly way, but ironically, no oneâ€”not even scholars, governments, or the United Nationsâ€”realizes that it is the primary cause of our current abnormal weather. This is obvious, however, with a little calculation. Sunlight is low-density, but over a large area it produces enormous amounts of energy. As I've said many times, 1 square meter produces roughly 1 kW. Therefore, 1 square kilometer produces 1 million kW. This is roughly the equivalent of a nuclear power plant. Covering forests and grasslands with black solar panels might produce 20% of the electricity, but the rest will become heat. Plants transpire, and through photosynthesis, they capture sunlight as chemical energy rather than heat. Even in the desert, the reflectivity is higher than that of black panels, and they return light back into space. The meteorological community needs to realize this sooner rather than later. China has installed 5,000 square kilometers of panels. This is where today's major disasters are coming from. If the current climate change were caused by carbon dioxide, the Southern Hemisphere would reach the same concentration within a few months, so it's reasonable for abnormal weather to occur. However, we haven't heard many reports of major disasters from Australia, southern Africa, or South America. This is likely due to the lack of mega-solar power plants. Japan, a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, has remained relatively safe despite its large number of mega-solar power plants. Typhoons and other storms are only partially prevented by China's gigantic mega-solar power plants. However, linear rain bands and sudden heavy rainfall are likely caused by solar power generation.

While it's almost certain that the cause of the devastating disasters is the black solar panels, the worst offenders are the mega-solar power plants built in forests and grasslands. These generate excess heat of the order of 1 million kW in hundreds or thousands of locations. It's inconceivable that climate change won't occur. Meanwhile, those installed on roofs originally made of black tiles are completely unaffected. However, if we want to avoid scorching urban areas, we should increase the number of colored or white roofs. Japan is a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, so we've been somewhat spared so far, but linear rain bands and localized disasters will inevitably increase. We should build white areas near the mega-solar power plants we've already built to return light to space and maintain heat balance. We could also lay white sheets on the undergrowth in forests, which seems effective in winter, but it's unclear how it would work in summer.

The reason for this severe disaster is the fact that mega-solar power plants using black solar power generation are the most important. The worst of these are those built in forests or grasslands. At noon on a sunny day, one square kilometer generates about 60% of the excess heat of a 1,000,000-kilometre nuclear power plant. Japan has 500 square kilometers of mega-solar power plants. Those installed on roofs with black tiles are barely affected. If possible, we should move away from jet-black tiles and use light-coloured or whitish tiles, especially in urban areas. In Japan, ocean current power generation is an immediately feasible alternative to solar power. This method has already been proposed, but even this would change the ocean currents if done on too large a scale. Existing mega solar plants should have white areas around them to return any excess heat generated back into space.

We asked an AI about the impact of the total solar panels in Japan and China. Here's the answer:

A 5,000 kmÂ² area of â€‹â€‹panels receives an average of about 1 TW of solar radiation, of which about 200 GW is electricity and about 800 GW is ultimately released into the surrounding area as heat.

Covering high-albedo areas such as deserts with black panels is estimated to result in an additional absorption (excess heat) of about 250 GW (on average).

While these figures are large enough to alter local weather, their relationship to the global greenhouse effect (COâ‚‚, etc.) requires separate quantitative comparison and verification using atmospheric circulation models (climate models).

To summarize:
The statement that "Even the butterfly effect has an impact, so it's not surprising that such a large energy change would cause abnormal weather" is intuitively and physically reasonable. However, the "magnitude of the contribution" has yet to be quantified academically.

We also asked another AI. See below.
Summary (Conclusion)

Based on assumptions (peak 1,000 W/mÂ², 20% efficiency, 5,000 kmÂ², 5 peak sunshine hours), this would result in an average continuous release of approximately 833 GW of excess heat (equivalent to approximately 833 1-GW nuclear reactors), equivalent to approximately 7,300 TWh of excess energy per year.

The figure is "very large"â€”the local heating potential is not negligible. However, whether this immediately represents the "largest cause of global extreme weather" requires additional climate modeling that thoroughly evaluates local effects, atmospheric circulation, ocean absorption, etc.

Seriously dangerous Typhoon. Hopefully those in the path of Ragasa aren't too badly impacted. Nice reference to the most intense Tropical Cyclone ever recorded (Typhoon Tip in 1979). Fun fact about that Typhoon: along with being the most intense it was also the largest Tropical Cyclone ever observed, with a wind diameter of 2,200km. Basically it was half the size of the mainland United States of America. On it's Wikipedia page there's a diagram of this, where it is placed alongside Cyclone Tracy that destroyed Darwin, Australia in 1974, one of the smallest Tropical Cyclones on record with winds extending only 48km from the centre of the storm.

"level buildings" - typhoon of that strength don't level modern buildings in Hong Kong, but they can level hits and small cardboard houses. It would do catastrophic damage in the Philippines, not HK/Macau. Luckily it mostly passes north of Luzon.

As a regular viewer from HK (with extended family in Melbourne), I was not expecting WW to cover RAGASA - but we'll take it for sure, so thank you Philip!

From a HK perspective, all the comparisions for RAGASA go straight back to Tropical Cyclone MANGKHUT in 2018 (also in September). We're still pretty scarred from what MANGKHUT did in 2018. What really struck was not just the wind destruction of some windows and trees, but the impact on natural shorelines (both from hurricane force winds and storm surge), with shoreline eroision and wind erosion of beaches - the sand from some far-out east-facing beaches was blown inland at least 100+ metres. As for rainfall, it's as about intensity as is totals. We get 50mm/hr regular enough during the wet season, but hike it up to 100+mm/hr in specific locations and the flash flooding and landslips really pile up. We wouldn't be surprised to see up to 500mm in a day, maybe even more in specific spots.

Horror moment super typhoon hits Hong Kong hotel

#hongkong #typhoon #ragasamania 

A wall of water burst through glass doors in the lobby of an up-market Hong Kong hotel, washing away guests and staff, as the â€œKing of Stormsâ€ battered the city.

Super Typhoon Ragasa has cut a deadly path through the region with at least 14 people killed in Taiwan and more than 100 injured across the disputed island nation and Hong Kong.

Dramatic footage has emerged of the moment murky water crashed against the closed glass doors of the Fullerton Ocean Park Hotel in Hong Kongâ€™s Aberdeen district.

The powerful seawater rush shattered the glass before sweeping through the building as hotel staff and guests clung to the walls for safety.

A man who had been holding onto a panda-themed cardboard display was pushed off his feet before a fellow guest rushed to help him stand.

Local media reported that massive waves breached the hotelâ€™s sandbags and protective barriers.

Typhoon Ragasa, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Nando, is an extremely powerful tropical cyclone that has been affecting parts of East and Southeast Asia in late September 2025. It is considered the most intense tropical cyclone worldwide so far this year.Â  
Here are some key details about Typhoon Ragasa (Nando):
Meteorological History:
â€¢ Formation: It originated from an area of convection on September 17, 2025.Â  
â€¢ Intensification: The storm underwent rapid intensification and was classified as a typhoon on September 19, and later reached the status of a violent typhoon and a Category 5-equivalent super typhoon.Â  
â€¢ Peak Intensity: At its peak, Ragasa had a minimum central pressure of 905 hPa and 10-minute sustained winds of 205 km/h (125 mph) according to the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assessed its 1-minute sustained winds to be even higher, at 270 km/h (165 mph).Â  
â€¢ Philippine Name: The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) named the storm "Nando" when it entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR).Â  
Path and Impact:
â€¢ Philippines: Typhoon Ragasa (Nando) has had a significant impact on the northernmost parts of Luzon, particularly the Babuyan and Batanes Islands. Authorities have issued high-level storm warnings, with warnings of life-threatening storm surges exceeding three meters, and destructive winds and torrential rain. Mass evacuations have been carried out in high-risk areas, and classes and government work have been suspended in numerous provinces.Â  
â€¢ Taiwan: The outer bands of the typhoon have affected Taiwan, leading to school and office closures and evacuations in southern counties. There is a risk of landslides and flooding in mountainous regions.Â  
â€¢ China and Hong Kong: The typhoon is forecast to continue westwards through the Luzon Strait before approaching southern China. Cities like Shenzhen have prepared for the storm by relocating hundreds of thousands of people from low-lying and coastal areas. Hong Kong is also on alert and preparing for potential typhoon-force winds. The storm is expected to weaken gradually as it crosses the South China Sea.Â  
â€¢ Vietnam: After affecting China, the typhoon is forecast to make landfall along the northern coast of Vietnam, near the Gulf of Tonkin, as a weakening but still significant typhoon.Â  
Wider Context:
The rapid intensification of Typhoon Ragasa is consistent with a broader trend of more powerful and destructive storms, which scientists attribute to warming oceans. This highlights the vulnerability of regions like the Philippines, which are already prone to tropical cyclones.

Typhoon Ragasa, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Nando, is an extremely powerful tropical cyclone that has been affecting parts of East and Southeast Asia in late September 2025. It is considered the most intense tropical cyclone worldwide so far this year.Â  
Here are some key details about Typhoon Ragasa (Nando):
Meteorological History:
â€¢ Formation: It originated from an area of convection on September 17, 2025.Â  
â€¢ Intensification: The storm underwent rapid intensification and was classified as a typhoon on September 19, and later reached the status of a violent typhoon and a Category 5-equivalent super typhoon.Â  
â€¢ Peak Intensity: At its peak, Ragasa had a minimum central pressure of 905 hPa and 10-minute sustained winds of 205 km/h (125 mph) according to the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assessed its 1-minute sustained winds to be even higher, at 270 km/h (165 mph).Â  
â€¢ Philippine Name: The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) named the storm "Nando" when it entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR).Â  
Path and Impact:
â€¢ Philippines: Typhoon Ragasa (Nando) has had a significant impact on the northernmost parts of Luzon, particularly the Babuyan and Batanes Islands. Authorities have issued high-level storm warnings, with warnings of life-threatening storm surges exceeding three meters, and destructive winds and torrential rain. Mass evacuations have been carried out in high-risk areas, and classes and government work have been suspended in numerous provinces.Â  
â€¢ Taiwan: The outer bands of the typhoon have affected Taiwan, leading to school and office closures and evacuations in southern counties. There is a risk of landslides and flooding in mountainous regions.Â  
â€¢ China and Hong Kong: The typhoon is forecast to continue westwards through the Luzon Strait before approaching southern China. Cities like Shenzhen have prepared for the storm by relocating hundreds of thousands of people from low-lying and coastal areas. Hong Kong is also on alert and preparing for potential typhoon-force winds. The storm is expected to weaken gradually as it crosses the South China Sea.Â  
â€¢ Vietnam: After affecting China, the typhoon is forecast to make landfall along the northern coast of Vietnam, near the Gulf of Tonkin, as a weakening but still significant typhoon.Â  
Wider Context:
The rapid intensification of Typhoon Ragasa is consistent with a broader trend of more powerful and destructive storms, which scientists attribute to warming oceans. This highlights the vulnerability of regions like the Philippines, which are already prone to tropical cyclones.

Black solar panels are the biggest cause of this once-in-a-century weather phenomenon. Solar power generation began as a way to utilize solar energy in an environmentally friendly way, but ironically, no oneâ€”not even scholars, governments, or the United Nationsâ€”realizes that it is the primary cause of our current abnormal weather. This is obvious, however, with a little calculation. Sunlight is low-density, but over a large area it produces enormous amounts of energy. As I've said many times, 1 square meter produces roughly 1 kW. Therefore, 1 square kilometer produces 1 million kW. This is roughly the equivalent of a nuclear power plant. Covering forests and grasslands with black solar panels might produce 20% of the electricity, but the rest will become heat. Plants transpire, and through photosynthesis, they capture sunlight as chemical energy rather than heat. Even in the desert, the reflectivity is higher than that of black panels, and they return light back into space. The meteorological community needs to realize this sooner rather than later. China has installed 5,000 square kilometers of panels. This is where today's major disasters are coming from. If the current climate change were caused by carbon dioxide, the Southern Hemisphere would reach the same concentration within a few months, so it's reasonable for abnormal weather to occur. However, we haven't heard many reports of major disasters from Australia, southern Africa, or South America. This is likely due to the lack of mega-solar power plants. Japan, a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, has remained relatively safe despite its large number of mega-solar power plants. Typhoons and other storms are only partially prevented by China's gigantic mega-solar power plants. However, linear rain bands and sudden heavy rainfall are likely caused by solar power generation.

While it's almost certain that the cause of the devastating disasters is the black solar panels, the worst offenders are the mega-solar power plants built in forests and grasslands. These generate excess heat of the order of 1 million kW in hundreds or thousands of locations. It's inconceivable that climate change won't occur. Meanwhile, those installed on roofs originally made of black tiles are completely unaffected. However, if we want to avoid scorching urban areas, we should increase the number of colored or white roofs. Japan is a long, narrow country surrounded by the sea, so we've been somewhat spared so far, but linear rain bands and localized disasters will inevitably increase. We should build white areas near the mega-solar power plants we've already built to return light to space and maintain heat balance. We could also lay white sheets on the undergrowth in forests, which seems effective in winter, but it's unclear how it would work in summer.

The reason for this severe disaster is the fact that mega-solar power plants using black solar power generation are the most important. The worst of these are those built in forests or grasslands. At noon on a sunny day, one square kilometer generates about 60% of the excess heat of a 1,000,000-kilometre nuclear power plant. Japan has 500 square kilometers of mega-solar power plants. Those installed on roofs with black tiles are barely affected. If possible, we should move away from jet-black tiles and use light-coloured or whitish tiles, especially in urban areas. In Japan, ocean current power generation is an immediately feasible alternative to solar power. This method has already been proposed, but even this would change the ocean currents if done on too large a scale. Existing mega solar plants should have white areas around them to return any excess heat generated back into space.

We asked an AI about the total impact of solar panels in Japan and China. Here's the answer:

A 5,000 kmÂ² panel area receives an average of about 1 TW of solar radiation, of which about 200 GW is electricity and about 800 GW is ultimately released into the surrounding area as heat.

Covering high-albedo areas such as deserts with black panels is estimated to result in an additional absorption (excess heat) of about 250 GW (on average).

While these effects are large enough to alter local weather, their relationship to the global greenhouse effect (COâ‚‚, etc.) requires separate quantitative comparison and verification using atmospheric circulation models (climate models).

In summary:
The statement that "Even the butterfly effect has an impact, so it's not surprising that such a large energy change would cause abnormal weather" is intuitively and physically reasonable. However, the "magnitude of the contribution" has yet to be quantified academically.

As a map geek, I wince a little bit when Robert refers to the Babuyan Islands as Batanes like at 2:10. There are two groups of islands in the Luzon Strait, the Batan Islands (the three northernmost small islands shown at 2:10) which compose the whole province of Batanes and whose capital is Basco (which Robert has mentioned a few times), and the Babuyan Islands, which are the slightly larger 5 islands closer to Luzon and are fully part of the province of Cagayan. (Four of the islands compose the municipality of Calayan while the other is part of Aparri, another town frequently mentioned by Robert.)

Ideas to Reduce Traffic in Pune/Delhi
(Please share further so it reaches the right authorities for decision-making)
1. Commercial Complexes Above Metro Stations
Currently, Pune and Delhi have metro stations every 2â€“3 km, but large construction areas around them are underutilized. If the government develops multi-storey commercial complexes (4â€“5 floors) directly above or attached to metro stations, it can bring multiple benefits:
Reduced City Travel: People can shop, eat, or access services as soon as they exit the metro, without needing to drive into crowded city centers.
Increased Metro Usage: Shoppers and commuters will prefer metro travel over private vehicles.
Government Revenue: Rental income from shops, malls, and offices above metro stations.
Convenience: Integrated â€œmetro + shoppingâ€ experience saves time for citizens.
Lower Pollution: Less reliance on cars and bikes for shopping trips will reduce congestion and emissions.
2. High-Rise Residential Development Near IT Parks
In Pune and Delhi, most IT professionals purchase flats 15â€“20 km away from IT hubs due to high property costs near workplaces. This leads to heavy daily traffic. A solution is to allow and encourage 35â€“45 floor skyscrapers near IT Parks instead of limiting buildings to 12â€“15 floors.
Benefits:
Reduced Commute: More employees living close to IT Parks = fewer vehicles on roads.
Efficient Land Use: Instead of spreading out into far suburbs, vertical development accommodates more families in limited space.
Lower Infrastructure Cost: Less need to build long new roads, electric lines, or water pipelines to far-off suburbs.
Integrated Living: Skyscrapers can include:
2â€“3 floors of commercial spaces (shops, groceries, services)
3â€“4 floors of dedicated parking
35+ floors of residential apartments
This ensures peopleâ€™s daily needs (shopping, services, parking) are all within walking distance.
Better Safety & Management: With concentrated housing, CCTV and security personnel can manage law and order more efficiently.
Environmental Benefit: Compact vertical housing preserves green/open areas instead of uncontrolled urban sprawl.
3. Policy Recommendations
Reduce permissions for independent plot-based constructions in core city areas.
Mandate minimum 20â€“25 storey buildings in city zones to optimize land usage.
Prioritize citizen benefit over political influenceâ€”decisions should serve the country, not personal property interests.
Overall Benefits for the Country:
âœ… Reduced road traffic & fuel consumption
âœ… Lower air pollution and carbon footprint
âœ… Better urban planning & disciplined city growth
âœ… Increased government revenue (commercial rentals, taxes)
âœ… Time savings and improved quality of life for citizens
